body_text.text: gene encoding p58 of CBF3, as a starting point. In this paper, we describe the identification of the SKP1 gene as a dosage suppressor of a ctf13-30 mutant. Genetic and biochemical analysis indicates that the 22.3 kDa Skp1 protein is a fourth subunit of CBF3 that was previously unrecognized. Unlike the other CBF3 components, Skp1p is a highly conserved protein found in multicellular eukaryotes. Furthermore, Skp1p has recently been shown to be a component of a cyclin A-cyclin-dependent kinase 2 (CDK2) complex purified from transformed human fibroblasts and to interact directly with Cdc4p and cyclin F through a novel structural motif (Bai et al., 1996 [this issue of Cell]). We conclude that Skp1p is involved in both structural and regulatory functions and may provide a direct link between the kinetochore and the cell cycle machinery.
